Award.AwardTitle: Fostering (STEM) Identity through the Transition (FIT) to College among Underrepresented Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority (URM) populations to successfully complete high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. The Broadening Participation Research (BPR) funding opportunity provides three-year support to enhance the understanding of the underlying issues affecting the differential participation and success rates of students from underrepresented groups in STEM. Using the Fostering Identity through Transitions (FIT) model, researchers at Stony Brook University (SBU) will study cohorts of STEM and non-STEM majors to test the FIT model with STEM programs, such as the SUNY LSAMP program, that seem likely to boost STEM identity by providing STEM skills training, research mentoring, and community building opportunities that parallel the FIT model components. The research fills important scientific knowledge gaps in broadening participation of underrepresented groups in STEM by conducting an in-depth theory-driven examination of the needed experiences that lead to engagement, retention, and overall success versus withdrawal among URM and non-URM students particularly during the first two years of college matriculation.

The aim of the three-year study is to test whether the FIT model can be used to predict STEM success outcomes among students from historically underrepresented populations. A quantitative and qualitative data intensive methodological approach of "experience sampling" will be employed to capture pivotal academic and social experiences that lead to college success during critcal first and second year transition. An interdisciplinary advisory board will provide oversight of the project. Project results will be disseminated broadly via the institution's website, publishing of scholarly articles, conference presentations, and among institutional administrators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Persistent and pervasive stereotypes about the competence and achievement of historically underrepresented (URM) students in STEM fields can impact students’ sense of belonging, identity and efficacy in academic spaces. The alienation and stereotypes that students’ encounter can undermine  motivation, confidence, sense of comfort and fit with peers, and belonging within academia and the broader STEM field (e.g., Brainard & Carlin, 1998; Good, Rattan, & Dweck, 2012; London, Rosenthal, & Gonzalez, 2011; London, Rosenthal, Levy & Lobel, 2011; Murphy, Steele, & Gross, 2007). As a testament to the presence of such effects, URM students often report having less positive contact with faculty (Crawford & MacLeod, 1990), less mentoring, fewer opportunities for advancement (e.g., Ferreira, 2003), and lower self-confidence than their majority group peers in STEM (e.g., Erwin & Maurutto, 1998). Based on this literature, we developed the Fostering Identity through Transitions (FIT) Model, which focuses on critical psychosocial factors in predicting STEM success among students. First, the FIT model of STEM success highlights that a strong and stable STEM identity is en via: [1] STEM academic-efficacy, [2] supportive mentoring relationships and [3] sense of belonging with peers and the University (e.g., Eccles, 1994; Larose, Ratelle, Guay, Senecal, & Harvey, 2006; London, Rosenthal, et al, 2011; Rosenthal, London, Levy, & Lobel, 2011; Rosenthal, London, Levy, Lobel, & Herrera-Alcazar, 2011). Second, the FIT model also points to the importance of fostering the development and maintenance of a STEM identity during critical transitional periods such as the first two years of college.

We utilized a quantitative and qualitatively data intensive methodological approach of experience sampling (multiple questionnaires during fall and spring semesters each year) that captures the pivotal academic and social experiences that lead to engagement, retention, and overall success during the first two years of college.

Across multiple timepoints during the transition to college, we have found consistent evidence that STEM identity, efficacy and belonging are critical constructs in predicting student engagement in STEM domains. Consistent with existing literature, the longitudinal data demonstrates that URM students who have concerns about identity-based discrimination report significantly lower science self-efficacy, academic confidence, interest and excitement in pursuing a STEM career and identification with their STEM discipline.  Comparison of students enrolled in URM focused enrichment programs highlights the importance of the STEM component of enrichment programs. URM students participating in LSAMP and CSTEP (URM STEM enrichment programs) showed equally strong STEM self-efficacy and career and major excitement compared to non-enrichment European American peers over their first year of college. These findings suggest that LSAMP and CSTEP students may be deriving psychosocial benefits from the STEM specific enrichment they have via their respective programs, while the non-STEM specific (i.e., general enrichment) of EOP/AIM may not contribute to gains in STEM efficacy and career engagement among those students. Although these findings highlight the challenges to efficacy, identity and belonging faced by URM students in STEM disciplines during the transition to college, other findings point to mechanisms of support that can mitigate the negative experiences of threat for URM students. First, STEM specific enrichment programs may strengthen identity and efficacy for URM students. Second, consistent mentorship during the transition to college predicts positive benefits for URM students. Our findings demonstrate that when students engaging with a consistent mentor over the transition to college, their academic efficacy and sense of belonging within the institution and STEM field is strengthened over time, compared to students who had inconsistent or no mentoring during the transition to college.   

This proposal aims to fill important scientific knowledge gaps in broadening the participation of URM students in STEM by conducting an in-depth, theory-driven examination of the pivotal experiences that lead to engagement, retention, and overall success among students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, during the college transition.  Our findings highlight the critical importance of early and consistent mentoring during the transition to college, as well as the benefits of STEM specific environment programs for building students’ efficacy, identity and belonging.
